item.title: code like a girl
item.description: I recently teamed up with code like a girl for a series of Data Storytelling presentations around Australia. Here’s a link list of some of the resources mentioned. The slide presentation also has a lot of links to check out, too. Data Storytelling resources name type tidyverse R metapackage for tidy data R for Data Science book RStudio Community forum Data Storytelling slides Data Storytelling script github repo R-Ladies themed slides tutorial leaflet R package for interactive maps

item.title: how I organise my thoughts and time
item.description: my current systems Updated: 2018-11-06 (I wonder if all or some of this should move to the dontpanic readme.) current tweaks switch \(\Phi, \theta, \varphi\) after planning \(\cdot\) pieces piano practice/task switching/pomodoor bullet journal, used to be as portable as possible blog to see if I’ve made any progress on my study problems for today, to track my productivity system, and to learn about my research problems; in short, blog for me, don’t worry about anyone else: but keep it to those three categories; one category per post, etc.

item.title: statistical rethinking
item.description: # packages library(tidyverse) library(patchwork) I’ve joined a bookclub Chapter Two Practice Easy Question One Which of the expressions below correspond to the statement: the probability of rain on Monday? P(rain) P(rain|Monday) P(Monday|rain) P(rain,Monday)/P(Monday) Answer Choices (2) and (4). I went looking for solutions and came across this, “the probability of rain on Monday” I think the statement could be interpreted in two different ways. First, the statement might just mean “what is the probability of rain on any given day”.
